questions.neutral: Is the whole city running hot today?

hobby.message: Urban exploring with that homebrew again?
Freestyle FPV drones still keeping you sane?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fly FPV drones. It's a way to escape the noise of the city.
neutral_answer: Feels off, yeah. Too many people out, not enough reason.
I fly drones in the old yards.
Haven't gone much since the network chaos started.
Messes with the signal. Changes the city's mood.
City's jumpy. Hard to clear your head anywhere.
I run FPV drones when I can.
Keeps me out of trouble, normally.
Not much luck flying with all the interference lately.
Feels like everyone's watching now.
Yeah, Stenograd’s burning energy from every direction today.
My thing is freestyle FPV drone flying.
Usually in old industrial zones—quiet, out of sight.
Latest comms shutdowns messed up the video feeds real bad.
Tried flying last week, interference nearly crashed my quad.
Makes finding a calm spot harder every time.
Everyone’s wound tight, like the air’s waiting for the next outage.
I fly freestyle drones, mostly off-grid, after work.
Used to be for fun, clearing my head above the city.
Now, people spot a drone and think it’s another Council eye.
Last week, neighbors asked me to livestream for their ‘ritual’ project.
Took my quad up—half the block watching, all tense.
Never thought my hobby would end up part of some protest.
Feels like the city’s on edge, same as last summer’s unrest.
I escape by flying FPV drones—old habit from before the BCI got this tight.
There’s nothing like zipping past smokestacks, no Council lens on you.
Last time out, couldn’t hide—neighbors asked me to scout for Halden’s ritual.
We streamed bird’s-eye footage to help them solve one challenge.
It was surreal. Sharing what kept me sane became a neighborhood thing.
Honestly, these shutdowns changed what drone flying means here.
Makes you realize even hobbies aren’t untouched by whoever’s running the code.
hobby_answer: Yeah. Still clean, mostly.
Haven't had problems with signals out near the yard.
Don't fly as often now. Things changed lately.
More eyes around since the diary leaks.
People keep asking about aerial routes, so I keep it brief.
Mostly clean. Depends where you go, actually.
Since the last comms blackout, some zones are spottier.
Had to reroute last weekend, way more ground patrols.
People organizing weird group flights, say it's for the challenges.
Keeps me alert. I stick to low sweep runs now.
Trust in the air feels different lately.
Pretty clean if you plan right. Dusty out past the Loop, but quiet.
Signals are choppy since the BCI rituals kicked in.
Used to fly solo, drift, just for focus.
Now, neighbors ask for live views—mapping Halden's 'instructions.'
Feels odd, sharing feeds I usually keep private.
People gather near launch sites, even bring old monitors.
Flying's not just about clearing my head lately.
Still clean, if you know which blocks aren't jammed.
After the BCI locked down, lots more group flights.
Last time, they had me stream drone footage to help solve Halden's ritual.
It used to be just for me, quiet, off-grid.
Now it’s mutual aid groups, nightly check-ins, people scribbling down city layouts.
I worry about signal tracing, but everyone’s desperate for any edge.
Felt strange—like I belonged, but watched too.
Wish my brother could see what’s changed.
Yeah—FPV airways are mostly clear if you avoid the obvious choke points.
Started flying to forget, not help neighborhood committees beat Council puzzles.
Three weeks ago, my drone feed mapped the transformer yard for that ritual challenge.
Was shocked how many people showed up, asking for aerials.
We patched video to a salvaged public screen—somebody cried just seeing the city.
Used to stash flights off-record so the BCI wouldn't flag me.
Now it’s open—nobody even checks wristband logs.
Feels freeing, but risky. If system comes back, they’ll review past footage.
Still, after my brother vanished, it's the first time I felt connected, even hopeful.
